                                                            Shaw Industries Group, Inc.

                                                                          Plant 8S

                                                                       Columbia, SC







Shaw Industries Group, Inc., Plant 8S:                                                                                                               

                                                                                                                                                                                      The Shaw Industries Group, Inc., Plant 8S is a polyester fiber and nylon resin and fiber manufacturing facility located in Columbia, South Carolina that has approximately 350 employees. The plant's products are used to make a variety of different types and styles of nylon and polyester carpeting.  The one material used by the facility which is on the RMP Rule's list of regulated substances is cyclohexylamine.  The Shaw Industries Plant 8S's storage and use of cyclohexylamine exceeds the specified threshold as defined by the EPA's RMP Rule.  The Shaw Industries Columbia Plant 8S is committed to managing health, safety and the environment as a core business value and operates under an established HS&E Management System based on the ISO 14001 and OHS&S 18001 Standards. The Plant also integrates health, safety and environmental management into all aspects of its operations as a competitive advantage in achieving profitable growth and accelerated productivity.  



In accordance with the requirements of the RMP Rule, a description of the following six elements is provided for the Shaw Industries Group, Inc., Plant 8S, Columbia, S.C.: 



1)  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies: 



It is the policy of the Shaw Industries, Columbia S.C. Plant 8S to operate a safe and environm

entally sound facility by identifying and controlling health, safety, and environmental risks related to its operations; by designing its processes to protect people, property and the environment; by conducting and continually reviewing and improving programs for safety, health and environmental excellence; and by establishing processes for the management of change and to ensure that all laws and regulations applicable to its operations and products are known and observed.  The accidental release prevention and emergency response policy associated specifically with the plant's use of cyclohexylamine involves the integration of safety devices and technologies inherent in the design of the process, safe operational procedures and management practices, operator training, the preparation and testing of site emergency response plans, the maintenance of onsite emergency response equipment and a professionally trained Emergency Response Team, coordinating our efforts and resources with local emergency response services, and communicating with the community. 



2)  Description of the Facility and the Regulated Substance Handled:  



The Shaw Industries, Columbia, S.C. Plant 8S uses cyclohexylamine as an additive in the manufacturing of nylon resin.  It is stored and handled in quantities that exceed the threshold quantity specified in the RMP Rule.  The Plant's stationary source of cyclohexylamine consists of bulk storage and process distribution equipment located as part of the Polymerization Department on the eastern side of the Plant site.  Cyclohexylamine is purchased from an outside vendor and is delivered to the Plant via tank truck on an "as needed" basis.  The tanker's contents are unloaded by Plant operators into an above ground bulk storage tank identified as VT-993 which is located in an isolated outdoor area. Cyclohexylamine is pumped from the bulk storage tank through an enclosed piping system into the production area where it is fed into the nylon polymeriza

tion process unit.  



3) The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:                                                                                                                                                                    

The general accidental release prevention program at Shaw Industries, Columbia, S.C. Plant 8S for the cyclohexylamine stationary source includes the following elements: a) established process safety management system for oversight and control of the cyclohexylamine process; b) development and implementation of accurate procedures for safe operation and maintenance of the process;  c) an on-going mechanical integrity program that ensures critical process equipment is designed, constructed, and installed in accordance to codes and standards and is also inspected, tested and proactively maintained;  d) performance of process hazards analysis with prompt resolution of any recommendations;  e) use of safety shutdown, relief and vent systems, interlocks, dikes and other secondary containment installations, control instrumentation, and process monitoring for early warning and detection;  f) implementation of procedures designed to review and manage changes to the process;  g) performance of incident investigations, process safety audits, and pre-startup safety reviews; and  h) a thorough area-specific training program for process operators and maintenance personnel.  Chemical-specific prevention steps include:  a) developing an understanding among the operators for the hazardous properties of cyclohexylamine along with the process chemistry and safe operational process limits such as temperatures, pressures, and flows;  b) understanding the benefits of safe chemical handling and the consequences of process deviations and inadvertent mixing of incompatible chemicals;  c) having knowledge of the requirements, capabilities and limitations of both personal protective and emergency response equipment

and maintaining easily accessible inventories of each;  d) designing the process technology and process equipment based on a thorough understanding of the hazardous properties of cyclohexylamine; and e) providing operators with specialized training for cyclohexylamine regarding its hazards and proper handling procedures. 



4)  The Five Year Accident History:  



1 accidental release from the cyclohexylamine stationary source has occurred at the Shaw Industries Columbia, S.C. Plant 8S in the past 5 years. On 7/28/2015, Polymerization associates were beginning to perform an unload of a cyclohexylamine tanker truck into VT-993 when the unload hose was disconnected from a nitrogen line still under pressure, causing residual cyclohexylamine in the hose itself to spray onto the observing associate. The observing associate was not wearing the same PPE required to be worn by the associate who was to perform the task of unloading the cyclohexylamine tanker truck. The associate who was sprayed with residual cyclohexylamine went under the emergency shower and partially removed his contaminated clothing. He exited the shower and walked approximately 200 yards to a different area of the site to remove the rest of his contaminated clothing, he then donned vinyl rain pants and rubber boots and walked to see his supervisor. Upon seeing what happened, the supervisor ordered the associate back under the emergency shower and he activated the site alarm system to notify the Plant Emergency Organization team. Upon arriving at the scene, 911 was called and PEO team members removed the remaining clothing and boots while the associate stayed under the emergency shower until emergency medical services arrived. After thorough rinsing, the associate was transported by ambulance to the medical helicopter pad where he was airlifted to the Charles Stills Burn Center at Doctors Hospital in Augusta, GA. He was hospitalized for 7 days. The associate performing the task of unloading noticed a sma

ll spot on the back of his neck as emergency medical services were leaving the site. He was placed under the emergency shower as the emergency medical services were flagged down before exiting the site. He was transported to the local emergency room where he was treated for a minor chemical burn and was released. There were no environmental impacts to this spill/release.  



5) The Emergency Response Plan:  



The Shaw Industries Columbia,S.C. Plant 8S has an emergency preparedness planning and response program designed to deal with accidental releases and other unplanned events associated with the facility's stationary source involving cyclohexylamine.  The Plant has a written Emergency Response Plan that addresses various types of contingencies including specific actions for responding to an accidental release of cyclohexylamine.  The Plan provides for both internal Plant and external community emergency alerting and notification with established call trees with multiple means of communication.  The Plan addresses emergency health care, in-place sheltering, evacuation, and implementation of an Incident Command System to direct and coordinate the Plant's response activities.  The Plan has been coordinated with the LEPC and with the local Fire Department who would direct offsite community response activities.  Members of the local Fire Department typically visit the Plant annually to receive training on the Site's RMP Program, the source location, the hazards of cyclohexylamine, the Site Emergency Response Plan and emergency response resources, and are taken on a tour of the facility.  The last RMP Emergency Response cross training with the local Fire Department was held at the Columbia Plant 8S in June of 2015.  The Fire Department's station house is physically located adjacent to the Columbia Plant 8S on adjoining property.  The Shaw Industries Columbia Plant 8S maintains its own professionally trained Emergency Response Team that is knowledgeable and prepared t

o respond to incidents involving accidental releases of cyclohexylamine.  The Plant 8S Emergency Response Team trains regularly and holds annual Plant emergency response drills and exercises.  Joint training exercises are conducted with members of the local Fire Department response group.  In-house testing and audits of the Plant's emergency response alarm and communication systems are performed weekly. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  



Even though air dispersion modeling results for the worst case release scenario of cyclohexylamine from the facility's largest container showed that the distance the vapors would travel to reach the toxic endpoint concentration would not exceed the Plant's property line, the Columbia, S.C. Plant 8S in August of 2005 relocated its largest storage container of cyclohexylamine approximately 700 feet further back from its original location in a direction away from the Plant's property line and the Plant's predominant employee population and process control operational areas.  The relocation of this bulk container increased the distance of the toxic endpoint to the Plant's nearest offsite property line by several hundred feet as calculated in the worst case release modeling.  The relocated cyclohexylamine tank storage and process distribution system became active on March 1, 2006.  Training with the local Fire Department has continued annually through the years and will be conducted again in 2016.  Plant 8S has established a formal Environmental, Health and Safety Management System following the requirements of the ISO 14001 and OHS&S 18001 standards.  The Site EH&S Management System provides a framework for conducting business in a safe and environmentally responsible manner and ensures the continual improvement of the Plant's safety and environmental management programs and practices, its commitment to regulatory compliance and to the prevention of pollution and injury or ill health of its employees, visitors and the community

, and establishes programs to manage and respond to change.  Plant 8S continues to improve the expertise and capabilities of its onsite emergency response teams with additional professional training and drills in the Incident Command System and Hazmat response.  Both Corporate and internal surveillance audits of the Plant 8S EH&S Management System are conducted annually to ensure that compliance and conformance to the programs' requirements are maintained.
